managed_header_modifications.table.title: HTTP request headers
HTTP response headers
managed_header_modifications.group.add_b: Adds HTTP request headers with bot-related values: bot score, verified bot, threat score, and JA3 fingerprint.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_v: Adds HTTP request headers with location information for the visitor's IP address, including city, country, continent, longitude, and latitude.
managed_header_modifications.group.remov: Removes HTTP request headers that may contain the visitor's IP address. Unavailable when "Add True-Client-IP header" is enabled.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_x: Adds several security-related HTTP response headers providing cross-site scripting (XSS) protection and defining a Content Security Policy (CSP).
managed_header_modifications.group.remov: Removes the "X-Powered-By" HTTP response header that provides information about the application at the origin server that handled the request.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_s: Adds several security-related HTTP response headers providing cross-site scripting (XSS) protection.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_t: Adds a "True-Client-IP" request header with the visitor's IP address. Unavailable when "Remove visitor IP headers" is enabled.
origin_rules.title: Origin rules
origin_rules.card.title: Origin rules
origin_rules.card.description:
Use Origin Rules to customize where matching traffic will go and with which parameters. Allows host header, resolve, destination port and SNI override.

 **You have used %{count_origin} of %{total_origin} origin rules.**
origin_rules.host_header.preserve: Maintains the host header from the original request.
origin_rules.destination_port.preserve: Maintains the destination port from the original request.
origin_rules.dns_record.preserve: Use the DNS records specified for the top level record
origin_rules.sni.preserve: Maintains the SNI value from the original request.
origin_rules.errors.all_preserved: Origin rule cannot preserve all parameters. Please select at least one parameter to rewrite.
origin_rules.errors.valid_port: Please enter a port number between %{min} and %{max}.

page-rules.additional-page-rules.title: Additional Page Rules
page-rules.description: Page Rules let you control which Cloudflare settings trigger on a given URL. Only one Page Rule will trigger per URL, so it is helpful if you sort Page Rules in priority order, and make your URL patterns as specific as possible.
page-rules.error.always_use_https.must_c: The URL must begin with "http://" for Always Use HTTPS to work.
page-rules.help:
### What are Page Rules?

Page Rules give you granular, URL-based control of Cloudflare's settings. The most important thing to know about Page Rules is that only one Page Rule will trigger on a URL, so it's important to sort your Page Rules in priority order, and keep your most specific Page Rules at the top.

#### What patterns are allowed in Page Rules?

 If you are using a Forwarding Page Rule, then you can map those wildcards to variables. In the forwarding URL, you can specify $1, $2 and so on that match the wildcards in the original URL, in order from left to right.

 For example, you could forward `http://*.example.com/*` to `http://$2.example.com/$1.jpg`. This rule would match `http://cloud.example.com/flare`, which would end up being forwarded to `http://flare.example.com/cloud.jpg`.

#### Some helpful tips:

1. If you want to match both http and https, it is enough to write example.com. You don't need to do *example.com.
2. If you want to match every page on a domain, you need to write example.com/*. It is not enough to write example.com.
3. Refer to [Understanding and Configuring Cloudflare Page Rules](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/218411427) for more details on Page Rule patterns.

#### What does Cache Everything do?

 In Page Rules, you can select an additional Caching Level that is only available in Page Rules: Cache Everything.  Cache Everything caches all content including html and dynamic/personalized content. That said, use with caution. It caches HTTP codes `200`, `301`, `302`, `303`, `403` and `404`. (Other HTTP response codes can be cached by specifying the URL and setting the Edge Cache TTL to "respect existing headers", assuming the origin allows caching.)

#### How do you specify cookie names for Bypass Cache Cookie or Cache on Cookie?

 *Note that Bypass Cache on Cookie is available only on Business and Enterprise plans & Cache on Cookie is Enterprise only.*
You can specify multiple cookie names by using the OR "|" operator. For example, to match `cookie1`, `cookie2`, or `cookie3`, you would write: `cookie1|cookie2|cookie3`. You can also use the wildcard ".*" operator, i.e. `cookie1.*`.

#### Bypass Cache on Cookie (Business & Enterprise) Tutorials: 

* [Caching Static HTML with WordPress/WooCommerce](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236166048)
* [Caching Static HTML with Magento (version 1 & 2)](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236168808)
* [Caching HTML with Drupal](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115002911927)
* [How do I cache static HTML?](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cache/best-practices/customize-cache) 

#### What do Resolve Override and Host Header Override do (Enterprise only)?

 Resolve Override changes the origin address that a request to a URL will be sent to. Host Override changes the Host Header on requests to that URL. More information is available on our knowledge base about [Resolve Override](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/206190798) and [Host Header Override](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/206652947).

page-rules.step.order.title: **Order:**
page-rules.step.order.description: This is the order in which your Page Rules will be triggered. Only one Page Rule will trigger per URL, so put your most specific Page Rules at the top.
page-rules.step.url.description: **If the URL matches:** By using the asterisk (*) character, you can create dynamic patterns that can match many URLs, rather than just one. All URLs are case insensitive. [Learn more about Page Rules](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/218411427).

transform-rules.title: Transform Rules
transform-rules.description: Use Transform Rules to transform your traffic. This includes **URL Normalization**, **URL Rewrites**, and **Header Modifications**. Transformed traffic is then used as input for other Cloudflare products.
transform-rules.rule_list.error: There was a problem fetching rules. Rules are still in effect on the edge. <0>Retry</0>

transform-rules.form.name.description: Give your rule a descriptive name

transform-headers.request.title: HTTP Request Header Modification rule
transform-headers.response.title: HTTP Response Header Modification rule
transform-headers.header.name: Header name
transform-headers.request_header.modify_: You can modify up to %{count} request headers
transform-headers.response_header.modify: You can modify up to %{count} response headers
transform-headers.request_header.form.to:
**Set header**
u2022 Replaces all existing header fields of a request with the entered value.
u2022 Adds the entered value to requests without any headers.
u2022 Where possible, we will keep the header in the same position.

**Remove header**
Remove all headers with this header name. If a header with this name does not exist, no action is taken.
transform-headers.response_header.form.t:
**Set header**
u2022 Replaces all existing header fields of a response with the entered value.
u2022 Adds the entered value to responses without any headers.
u2022 Where possible, we will keep the header in the same position.

**Remove header**
Remove all headers with this header name. If a header with this name does not exist, no action is taken.
transform.configuration.normalization_ty:
Select normalization type:
* RFC-3986: Adhere strictly to RFC-3986 and normalize the URI Path based upon the standards outlined within.
* Cloudflare: Apply additional normalization techniques; normalize back slashes into forward slashes and merge successive forward slashes.

Further information on these options can be found within the [documentation](https://developers.cloudflare.com/rules/normalization/how-it-works).
transform.configuration.normalize_incomi: Normalize incoming URL-encoded URLs as they reach Cloudflareu2019s edge. Cloudflare then uses the normalized URLs for products with URL input, including Page Rules, Firewall Rules, Workers, and Access.
transform.configuration.normalize_origin: In addition to URL normalization at Cloudflareu2019s edge, normalize URLs for traffic to the origin.
